Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Software Platform for Constructing Mission-critical Autonomous Distributed Systems
Award.AbstractNarration: The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a wide range of autonomous distributed systems, including cloud services, internet of things (IoT) and edge-computing capable factory systems, and autonomous distributed robotics. Heavy use of cloud services, proliferation of IoT (more than 30B devices and $1.5 trillion in spending by the end of 2020) and a developing need for complex autonomous devices (e.g., drone swarms) increases the demand for concurrent and distributed software solutions and their capabilities. While standard practices of software development meet demands in a portion of these areas, due to novel requirements of complex software there is a constant rise of the burden for software developers and domain experts. There is a need to shorten the time to deploy new systems but also enable more complex systems, fortified by guarantees in crucial aspects such as security, privacy, and performance.<br/><br/>This I-Corps project is based on the development of a general platform for constructing mission-critical autonomous distributed systems. The hypothesis is that these types of systems effectively require new models and tools for software development and ultimately user interfaces. The approach focuses on fundamental difficulties of distributed software construction and hides them from the concerns of the domain-expert (potentially non-programmer) end-user. It enables not just rapid prototyping and easier development but also construction of systems that perform a more complex sets of tasks, while producing optimal correct-by-construction systems. The goal is to empower domain-specific non-programmer experts, allowing them to focus on conceptual domain-specific tasks, while eliminating the burden of low-level distribution implementation details. The system is designed to provide a missing piece for enabling complex tasks on interconnected devices, especially the those operating under restricted environments, like autonomous drone swarms, opening new possibilities with such autonomy, such as advanced drone swarm missions.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project is based on research that resulted in an innovative platform designed to enable novel ways of constructing mission-critical autonomous distributed systems. These systems encompass a wide range of applications, from cloud-based systems to drone swarm systems. This platform focuses on streamlining the complex aspects of software development and integration that are inherent in such systems. Our solution capitalizes on the latest advancements in software engineering and programming languages research. By incorporating cutting-edge techniques and modern frameworks, we empower users to specify distributed systems using higher levels of abstraction. This approach allows them to focus on system behaviors without getting entangled in the intricacies of distribution and implementation, as these lower-level details are handled automatically. The outcomes of our research have been presented in multiple conferences, where we have showcased the potential of our technology. By utilizing our platform, developers can generate optimized code based on high-level specifications of the desired system behaviors. Furthermore, we have developed a runtime framework that can allow seamless deployment of the resulting systems across a network of interconnected devices.

Entering the NSF I-Corps Team program, the goal of this project was to explore industrial applications and potential pain points and challenges involved in development and optimization of distributed systems, a common foundation of many software and cyber-physical systems today. The underlying motivation was that a new approach would enable non-experts to construct distributed software and achieve their goals, with less cost and time required. Initially, the team had preliminary knowledge of software engineering and develop-ment practices from a technical perspective, but lacked in-depth first-hand knowledge of the relevant pain points and cost-drivers from an operational and economical perspective. Industries of interest at this point included the finance sector, big data, customer and industrial IoT vendors, and a variety of companies and institutions utilizing drone technologies.

The increasing utilization of cloud services, the rapid growth of interconnected devices (projected to exceed 50 billion devices by the end of 2030), and the emerging demand for sophisticated autonomous systems, such as robot swarms, have amplified the need for concurrent and distributed software solutions and their capabilities. Although conventional software development practices meet requirements in certain areas, the unique demands of complex software have imposed a growing burden on software developers and domain experts. There is a pressing need to expedite the deployment of new systems while accommodating the complexities of advanced systems, emphasizing critical aspects like security, privacy, and performance. However, current practices are inadequate to implement these requirements at the necessary scale and pace, posing significant challenges for many commercial systems. In response, our approach tackles the core complexities of constructing distributed software and shields them from the concerns of end-users who are domain experts. By doing so, we empower individuals in various roles to expand their impact, facilitate the production of systems at reduced costs and enhanced efficiency, and open avenues for the development of novel systems.

As a result of this NSF award, the team was able to conduct extensive customer research, a critical component in the process of translating our project for commercial and societal value. Building upon the insights gained from the NSF I-Corps program, the team successfully advanced their customer discovery process and secured acceptance into multiple accelerator programs. The NSF award played a pivotal role in facilitating interviews and workflow observations of individuals in diverse roles, allowing us to gain valuable insights into the specific needs of various companies and their corresponding ecosystems. This in-depth understanding of the problems we aim to address has enabled us to take significant strides towards developing a suitable Minimum Viable Product (MVP). Furthermore, the award has fostered deeper relationships with potential users, creating a valuable feedback loop for our ongoing research and development endeavors. This enhanced engagement and collaboration greatly contribute to our mission of delivering a successful and impactful end product, and changing how people view, construct, and use modern interconnected systems.
